title: U.K. Rents on the Rise as Supply Dwindles
text:
Buoyed by tightening supply and prohibitively high property purchase costs, rental growth across the U.K. rose 2% annually in the third quarter of the year, according to a report released Wednesday in the U.K. from Zoopla.



The increase marked the highest rate of growth in three years, and more than the 1.3% annual growth logged at the same time last year, the online real estate portal said,



More: Former Mayfair Home of Aviation Tycoon Sir Frederick Handley Page Asks £18.75M

“Growth has increased from a recent low of 0.6% in June 2017, as the supply of rental homes has tightened, with investors buying fewer homes and some rationalizing portfolios in the wake of 2016’s tax changes,” Richard Donnell, research director at Zoopla, said in the report.



In 2016, a 3% stamp duty tax surcharge was introduced for second homes and buy-to-let purchases, causing rental property investment to become more expensive.

“In regions and cities where supply is shrinking, the cost of renting is rising at an above-average rate, while weaker growth markets are registering faster growth in supply, running ahead of what is often rising demand,” Mr. Donnell said.



Further underpinning growth are rising employment and affordability constraints limiting access to home ownership—particularly in and around London—which supports underlying rental demand, the report said.

Across the 40 cities Zoopla analyzed, Nottingham, in the East Midlands, logged the highest annual rental growth in the third quarter, up 5.4%.



Growth in Leeds, in Yorkshire and the Humber, and Bristol, in South West England, followed. Each city saw prices rise 4.5% in the same time. Bristol is also home to the fastest-moving rental market, as homes in the city find a tenant in an average of nine days, the report said.



In London—where growth had been negative between September 2016 and the start of 2018—rental growth increased 2.3% in the third quarter.



Aberdeen, Scotland, was the worst-performing rental market, with values falling 4.1% annually. The coastal city, famed for its oil industry, has seen a decline in rental demand and rents since oil prices collapsed in 2015, the report said.
